channel.title: a blog of spaghettiwews
channel.description: Recent content on a blog of spaghettiwews

item.title: How to install/use Hugo in WSL (Ubuntu 18.04)
item.description: It’s been a while since I wrote on this blog and today when I git cloned the blog repo and attempted to update it, I quickly realised that I could not for the life of me remember all of the commands I needed to run in order to download the theme submodule and deploy the site after writing a new post. So, for my future self and posterity’s sake in this post I will be documenting the commands I need for installing Hugo, downloading the site and its theme(s), creating a new post and deploying it:

item.title: Using the C# Compiler at the Command Line
item.description: C:\>csc /t:library /out:reslib.dll mysource.cs csc /t:winexe /r:ctls1.dll /r:ctls2.dll winapp.cs csc /keyfile:strongkey.snk secure.cs

item.title: Using the System.Text.RegularExpressions.Regex class
item.description: string zipexp = @"\d{5}((-|\s)?\d{4})?$"; string addr = "W.44th St, New York, NY 10017-0233"; Match m = Regex.Match(addr,zipexp); // Static method Regex zipRegex = new Regex(zipexp); m = zipRegex.Match(addr); // Use Regex Object Console.WriteLine(m.Value); // 10017-0233 Pattern Description Example |Match one or more occurrence |ab+c matches abc, abbc |Match zero or more occurrences |ab*c matches ac, abbc ? |Matches zero or one occurrence |ab?

item.title: Formatting Date Values
item.description: DateTime Formatting: (January 19, 2005 16:05:20) en-US Format Value Displayed Format Value Displayed d 1/19/2005 Y or y January, 2005 D Wednesday, January 19, 2005 t 4:05 PM f Wednesday, January 19, 2005 4:05:20 PM T 4:05:20 PM F Wednesday, January 19, 2005 4:05 PM s 2005-01-19T16:05:20 g 1/19/2005 4:05 PM u 2005-01-19 16:05:20Z G 1/19/2005 4:05:20 PM U Wednesday, January 19, 2005 21:05:20PM M or m January 19

item.title: Formatting Numeric Values
DateTime and TimeSpan
item.description: DateTime Constructor DateTime(yr, mo, day); DateTime(yr, mo, day, hr, min, sec); DateTime bday = new DateTime(1964,12,20,11,2,0); DateTime newyr= DateTime.Parse("1/1/2005"); DateTime currdt = DateTime.Now; // also AddHours, AddMonths, AddYears DateTime tomorrow = currdt.AddDays(1); TimeSpan diff = currdt.Subtract(bday); // 14795 days from 12/20/64 to 6/24/05 Console.WriteLine("{0}", diff.Days); // TimeSpan(hrs, min, sec) TimeSpan ts = new TimeSpan(6, 30, 10); // also FromMinutes, FromHours, FromDays TimeSpan ts = TimeSpan.FromSeconds(120); TimeSpan ts = ts2 – ts1; // +,-,>,<,==, !

item.title: System.Text.StringBuilder
item.description: Constructor StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(); StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(mystring); StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(mystring,capacity); mystring – Initial value of StringBuilder objectcapacity – Initial size (characters) of buffer. Using StringBuilderMembers decimal bmi = 22.2M; int wt = 168; StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder("My weight is "); sb = sb.Append(wt); // can append number sb = sb.Append(" and my bmi is ").Append(bmi); // my weight is 168 and my bmi is 22.

item.title: String Operations
item.description: Compare String.Compare(stra, strb, case, ci) bool case – true for case insensitiveci – new CultureInfo(“en-US”)returns: < 0 if a < b, 0 if a = b, 1 if a > b IndexOf str.IndexOf(val, start, num) val – string to search forstart – where to begin in stringnum – number of chars to searchreturns (–1) if no match. LastIndexOf Search from end of string. Replace newstr = oldstr.Replace("old","new"); Split Char[] delim = {‘ ‘, ‘,’}; string w = "Kim, Joanna Leslie"; // create array with three names string[] names= w.

item.title: Arrays
item.description: Declaration int[] numArray = {1903, 1907, 1910}; int[] numArray = new int[3]; // 3 rows and 2 columns int[ , ] nums = {{1907, 1990}, {1904, 1986}, {1910, 1980}}; Array Operations Array.Sort(numArray); // sort ascending // Sort begins at element 4 and sorts 10 elements Array.Sort(numArray, 4,10); // Use one array as a key and sort two arrays string[] values = {"Cary", "Gary", "Barbara"}; string[] keys = {"Grant", "Cooper", "Stanwyck"}; Array.

item.title: Data Types
item.description: Primitive Size Example string 2 bytes/char s = “reference”; bool b = true; char 2 bytes ch = ‘a’; byte 1 byte b = 0x78; short 2 bytes Ival = 54; int 4 bytes Ival = 540; long 8 bytes ival = 5400; float 4 bytes val = 54.

item.title: On starting a new decade
item.description: bring it source: matrix revolutions | giphy

item.title: A list of open source projects
item.description: I like well designed software. I also like free things, as I’m sure do you. Every now and again these two qualities/properties/attributes intersect and I’ll stumble upon a free, cool piece of software that I reckon may be useful to me (or you) in the future. While there’s a 90% chance that I won’t ever use most of these, here’s a running list of said applications/systems/software nonetheless: Grafana - The open platform for analytics and monitoring https://grafana.

item.title: Using a reverse proxy to provide ssl to a wordpress site hosted on a non-https server
item.description: What’s a reverse proxy? well, in this context, wikipedia has this to say: In computer networks, a reverse proxy is a type of proxy server that retrieves resources on behalf of a client from one or more servers. In the case of secure websites, a web server may not perform SSL encryption itself, but instead offloads the task to a reverse proxy that may be equipped with SSL acceleration hardware.

item.title: Hello Hugo
item.description: Well hello there. This here is how this started: hugo -t black-and-light cd public git add . git commmit -m "initial commit" git push
